docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. and Japan in Deal To Increase Air Traffic The United States and Japan agreed to remove most restrictions on air traffic between the two countries, ending a longstanding dispute.
docs.snippet: U.S. and Japan in Deal To Increase Air Traffic  The United States and Japan agreed to remove most restrictions on air traffic between the two countries, ending a longstanding dispute.

docs.lead_paragraph: A bill was introduced in the State Assembly on Thursday that would allow patients to sue health maintenance organizations for malpractice if they are denied necessary tests or procedures. Currently, malpractice lawsuits are not allowed against the organizations. Instead, disagreements are taken to an appeals panel.

headline.main: Bill Would Allow Patients to Sue H.M.O.'s

docs.abstract: New Jersey Assembly will consider bill to allow patients to sue health maintenance organizations for malpractice if they are denied necessary tests or procedures (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna Inc., one of the largest insurance companies, has begun trying to sell its life insurance business in the United States to further concentrate on its main line, health care. In the last week or so, Aetna has quietly notified the leaders in the life insurance industry that its unit is for sale, people close to the company said.

headline.main: Aetna's Life Insurance Unit Is Reported to Be Up for Sale

docs.abstract: Aetna Inc begins trying to sell its life insurance business in US to further concentrate on its main line, health care; CNBC reports Aetna might buy Oxford Health Plans Inc (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-7 Blair Opens an Inquiry Into Irish 'Bloody Sunday' Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain said he was opening a new judicial inquiry into the ''Bloody Sunday'' killings of more than a dozen unarmed civil rights marchers by British soldiers in Northern Ireland in 1972. The event became a focus of Roman Catholic rage in the troubled province. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: Looking for new legislative successes after blocking President Clinton's fast-track trade bill last year, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. outlined an ambitious legislative agenda today that would raise the minimum wage and require employers to pay at least 75 percent of workers' health insurance premiums. At an executive council meeting here, the group's leaders also voiced support for bills that would require employers with more than 50 workers to offer pensions and would bar companies from paying part-time workers less an hour than they pay full-time workers who do equivalent work.

headline.main: After Derailing Trade Bill, Labor Sets Ambitious Goals

docs.abstract: AFL-CIO pres John Sweeney and other leaders of union, at executive council meeting in Washington, DC, outline ambitious legislative agenda that would raise minimum wage and require employers to pay at least 75 percent of worker's health insurance premiums (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton's 1998 agenda is brimful of new Federal initiatives to allay the anxieties and address the needs of people of every age, from infants to baby boomers to frail elderly women. White House officials conceded today what seemed obvious to Republicans: many of the proposals outlined in the State of the Union Message were chosen by the President because of their political appeal to potential voters in an election year. Good policy is good politics, White House officials boasted.

headline.main: White House Concedes Voter Appeal of Agenda
headline.kicker: STATE OF THE UNION: DOMESTIC PLANS
